Award.AbstractNarration:
This award funds a workshop to bring together indigenous cultural representatives from the great river basins of the Yukon and the Amazon with environmental scientists to share information and formulate plans for research on themes that highlight the long-term sustainability of rivers and the health and well-being of the people who live along them. Although the Amazon is a long way from the Arctic, their is a good argument for the need to connect the communities of river systems around the globe in order to better understand the effects of resource development, urbanization, and environmental change on these important fresh water systems. Although the global environmental change signal is strongest in the Arctic it is having an effect on other global river systems. And while urbanization and resource development may have a larger signal in the Amazon in all but the Russian arctic, these processes are spreading across the Circumpolar North. The PI and his collaborators view this workshop as a starting point a larger network of Indigenous Peoples and scientists working together to increase our understanding of these fresh water systems and ensure their long term sustainability and sustainable use. It is the vision of the research team that future workshops will include the Lena, Nile, Ganges, Yangtze, Gironde, Mississippi and the McKenzie Rivers and ultimately the Ocean Peoples of Polynesia.

The five-day workshop will be held in Timpia, Peru, fall 2013 with the specific goals to: gather and compare observations and experiences from workshop participants around issues of water and rivers, and how they have been impacted by landscape and environmental change; seek consensus among the participants about specific kinds of capacity development and action around water issues that may be needed to address community needs; introduce and train participants in methods of community-based water monitoring; introduce and train participants in methods of digital media and storytelling; identify methods for developing and maintaining community and information exchange among workshop participants, including the possible establishment of a global network centered around indigenous communities and rivers. Additional subjects explored during the workshop will be indigenous narratives of how rivers may have changed due to landscape and environmental change, both contemporary and traditional, in order to gain more insights into how communities have responded to these challenges and their dynamic effects on local social and cultural systems. Also discussed by workshop participants will be how modern science contributes tools and additional perspectives to understanding changes in the riverine environment. And, how science and traditional ecological knowledge (TEK) can work together for the benefit of indigenous communities. The workshop will include strong participation from both indigenous communities and the scientific community and thus will increase the participation of highly underrepresented groups in science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NIK

Network of Indigenous Knowledge

The Network of Indigenous Knowledge (NIK) is a network created to allow for the exchange of modern science and Indigenous Knowledge by Native pariticipants located on different watersheds around the globe.

The Yukon River Inter-Tribal Watershed Council, based on the Yukon River Watershed and made up of 70 Tribes and First Nations in the United States and Canada began working on this global network a few years ago. The foundation for the network lies in the work of the Council on the Yukon Watershed where they have created one of the largest Indigenous monitoring networks in the world. This system involves all 70 member nations along the entire length of the 2200 mile Yukon River in the collection and sharing of water quality data, permafrost data, and Indigenous Knowledge. The expansion, through a workshop in Peru, of this network was the vision of the Council to not only share their "lesson learned", but also their knowledge with other Native Watershed based groups. The Councils vision included the thought of including Indigenous Knowledge and modern science to allow Native People to assist in making decisions regarding the environment for the shared future of the planet.

This desire to share and compare this collective of information led to the Machiguenga People of the Urabamba River in the Amzonian Basin of Peru.  During the fall of 2013 representatives from The Council and the Gwich in and S'Klallam cultures traveled by airplane, overland road and canoe to reach the remote community of Timpia. All of that travel after many conversations with the Machiguenga over the years prior about their desires and hopes. Arriving in the community by canoe the Team from The Council was greeted warmly. They set to work immediately with community meetings and meetings with the Chief's. The instruction and training of community members that were selected by the Tribe were focused on modern water quality data collection, video and still photography cultural documentation and interview techniques. Over a nine day period classroom and "hands on" instruction was provided. At the same time "human to human" cultural exchange was the theme of the day. Everyone involved had much to share. The Machiguenga were amazed to learn of "fish wheels" used on the Yukon to catch Salmon while the Gwich in and S'Klallam representatives were treated to a day of fishing using a locally derived "fish pioson".  The Machiguenga provided everyone with the knowledge of 34 "worms" (larva) that make up part of their diet and provide some medicines to the Tribe. Though not very appetizing to most, interesting in that their collection and uses are passed down orally. Having not been video documented before they are now becoming part of the NIK database.  

Much was learned by all. World views and creation stories were shared amongst the group. A true human connection was established.

On the modern scientific side of things, the training provided and the science shared will prove invaluable to the cultures as we move into the future. Allowing these Native groups, seperated by vast distants, to collect, compare and share water quality data from their watersheds is an excercize in empowerment. Knowing what is happening with the water they depend on, being able to compare that with regions in other parts of the world will assist them with decisons about their shared future. At the same time it will give them a "seat at the table" in negoiations for on the environment and any planned development.
